lenders.name: Julia
lenders.loan_because:
I want to level the playing field by providing short - term microloans or medium - term housing microloans to people in need. I want transparency. I oppose huge loans. I want Kiva to mark the partner pages as self descriptions of partners and provide all the info that might be necessary to make an informed decision about the partners on a separate page. I expect Kiva to avoid even the impression of entanglement with any partner. _____________________________________________________________  I oppose Kiva´s partnership with Opus Dei because its undertaking, Strathmore, is no bank but a private *educational* institution and from the information that the GLBT team provided I draw the conclusion that Opus Dei works against women´s rights expecting them to think of themselves as carpets for others to step on [from the book "Gottes rechte Kirche"] ___________________________________________________________________ I feel that Kiva management has not provided any info whatsoever so far when being asked.____________________________________ _Kiva has opened its African headquarters on the campus of Strathmore University. When some lenders complained Matt Flannery said that Kiva could move anytime. He gave no information on why they didn´t plan to move. Even if there was no connection: If I led a charity and many lenders said they saw a problem with me renting bureaus from a certain organisation I would move to another location. If I stayed I would have to give detailed info on why exactly this spot it so great for me to stay at. _____________________________________________________________

If someone said one of my managers had a business connection that might create a conflict of interest I would address the issue, clarify what kind of business relationship there was and explain why I thought this did not pose a conflict of interest.

If lenders said that huge education loans were a mission shift away from the core mission I would discuss this._________________________________________________________

I found this article from Bilgrimage blogspot very interesting and I link it below:

"What I am saying is that the lack of transparency and honesty among Kiva's top leaders about their thick connections to Laurent Drion, who has been presented to us Kiva supporters as merely an exemplary altruist and certainly not as a venture capitalist moving electronic goods in Africa, has caused the Kiva-Strathmore deal to appear in a less than savory light--at least in the eyes of many of us. This is true a fortiori because Opus Dei has a well-documented history of seeking to recruit corporate and business elites through ties to business schools--schools exactly like Strathmore.___________________________________

Opus Dei is all about massaging capitalist elites to do the work of Christ, and doing that work without accountability and transparency--with the implication that Opus Dei's work is self-evidently and automatically good. Because it's for Christ, of course. And for capitalism . . . ."___________
This is Kiva staff´s latest response which I just found on the website but haven´t gone through,yet:
http://blog.kiva.org/faqs/strathmore-qa
lenders.occupational_info:
I help that the things our customers want delivered get to their customers.

Tradition is to preserve the fire and not to pray to the ashes.

Due to recent events I link an article about Kiva and Strathmore. I won´t make donations and only few loans until this is settled.

lenders.name: MARI
lenders.loan_because:
I believe that generally, people will 'live up to' a community's expectations for them. Thus, firmly believing someone will succeed generally leads to success as long as their community (family, friends, or even a global community) voices the expectation and provides direct or indirect support. Likewise, expecting someone to fail generally leads to failure. 
I believe that researched goals, firm plans, hard work, tenacity, are the keys to success. I also believe that reaching out our hand to help others is both our reward for succeeding and our responsibility no matter where we are in  our attainment of success.

I loan because I believe in humanity.

lenders.name: Steffi
lenders.loan_because: I want to give something god gave to me to other people who have great ideas and who need it!
lenders.occupational_info: I'm in Peru for 6.5 month to work in a social project of the local YMCA. This project is located in a very poor part of Arequipa. The ACJ (peruvian YMCA) founded a bakery and a knitting workshop for the poor women here and I work together with them - doing a lot of computer stuff but also building relations.

lenders.name: Gordon
lenders.loan_because: it is such an excellent way to help people change their lives, and I especially like that fact it can help women achieve a degree of independence.
lenders.occupational_info: I am a mechanical engineer who works for a company that provides computer software to the mining, utility and transport industries. My primary interest is the maintenance of mining equipment.
